Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: Lessons Learned From Model Tropical Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Building on almost two decades of field research in tropical systems of the Atlantic lowlands of Costa Rica, this project synthesizes information on relationships between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Over this time period, field studies that involved relatively simple experimental ecosystems comprising combinations of the most important plant life forms of the tropical rain forest were carried out. Through analysis of these experimental ecosystems, the role of biodiversity in ecosystem functioning was revealed, and the processes involved and mechanisms responsible for phenomena were observed. The objective of this research is to gain further, more synthetic, insights and understanding of the relationships among individual plant species and combinations of plant species, and factors that influence an ecosystem's
capacity to be sustained. This will be accomplished by integrating results reported in the project's 50 publications and 11 theses together with new analyses of existing data on soil, water, and vegetation.

The research will result in wide dissemination of findings through publications that target relatively broad audiences. Those publications will include, among others, a paper emphasizing the implications of the research for land use and restoration of ecosystem processes, plus a synthetic monograph that couples nutrient storage in vegetation and soil with nutrient flows linked to ecosystem processes such as productivity, leaching, and resource partitioning.

Students first trained through an Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) program will have an opportunity to be supported by this project and thereby gain experience in conducting synthesis research from large amounts of ecological data. The findings are intended to be applicable to ecological issues of broad importance to society, including the design of sustainable systems of land use and ecosystem restoration. By understanding the mechanisms and processes involved, resource managers will have improved ability to generalize and will be able to avoid having to treat each situation as unique.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective was to better understand how ecosystems function through synthesis of a large number of data sets from long-term field experiments in Costa Rica. The ecosystems differed in two traits: diversity and rate of turnover. Plots contained one, three, or five plant species; those containing one species were cut and replanted annually or every four years, or left uncut.  The research was conducted on fertile soil in the humid tropical lowlands, so plant growth was extremely fast and results were forthcoming in just a few years. As a result of the synthesis effort, we were able to answer, at least partially, two questions of very broad importance – one on productivity and one on nutrient loss.

1. Did more species lead to more production?

    In systems of one species or three, the answer was yes, but only temporarily. As the three-species systems developed, complementary use of resources (soil nutrients and water, light) by different species swiftly turned into compensatory growth, whereby a decline in one species was offset by a positive response in another. Compensatory growth, in turn, usually gave way to competition, whereby one species prevailed and the others became very minor contributors to productivity.    

    What led to severe competition, rather than sustained partitioning of resources? We first suspected that some essential element in the soil must be the limiting resource, but after examining many possibilities we eventually realized that we were looking in the wrong place: The answer lie not beneath our feet, but above our heads. Light was the key. The evergreen palms had grown upward, occupying what would have been crown space for tree leaves: The trees were out-competed for light from below.

    The story was different in mixtures containing five species, where all species survived, though some better than others. Furthermore, complementary use of resources among species increased steadily over time. How was this possible? Imagine a mixture of five species. They partition the aboveground space, and therefore the light they capture, in different ways: Species A has a broad, spreading crown; species B has very long, arching leaves; species C has a tall, narrow crown that fits into the interstices; and so forth. The result is higher productivity by the mixture of species than the average production of monocultures of each of the components.

2. Does species diversity exert more influence on soil fertility than stand turnover?

    There are two main pathways whereby soils on flat terrain lose nutrients: deep leaching and plant uptake. The implications of the two paths differ markedly, however: Nutrients leached are nutrients lost, whereas nutrients taken up by plants are lost from the soil, but are still in the ecosystem.

    Stands that were uncut did not leak significant amounts of nutrients, and those containing three species lost somewhat lower amounts than those with only one species. In striking contrast, fast-turnover stands hemorrhaged nutrients, especially nitrogen and calcium, and the more frequently they turned over, the more they lost.
